title: 103_hr4636
content: The "Employment Non-Discrimination Act of 1994" prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation in employment. It also specifies that employee benefits do not apply to partners and prohibits disparate impact. The Employment Non-Discrimination Act of 1994 prohibits discrimination based on sexual orientation in employment. It states that disparate impact does not establish a violation of the Act, prohibits quotas and preferential treatment based on sexual orientation, and provides a religious exemption for organizations, except for their for-profit activities subject to taxation. SEC. 7. NONAPPLICATION TO MEMBERS OF THE ARMED FORCES; VETERANS' PREFERENCES. The term "employment or employment opportunities" does not apply to the relationship between the United States and members of the Armed Forces. The term "Armed Forces" includes the Army, Navy, Air Force, Marine Corps, and Coast Guard. This Act does not affect any laws providing special rights or preferences for veterans. SEC. 8. ENFORCEMENT. Enforcement Powers: The Commission, Librarian of Congress, and Attorney General have powers to enforce the Act similar to those under the Civil Rights Act of 1964. District courts have jurisdiction to enforce the Act. Procedures and remedies for violations are specified. The procedures and remedies for violations of the Congressional Accountability Act differ based on the individual alleging the violation. For violations alleged by individuals other than House or Senate employees, procedures similar to those under Title VII of the Civil Rights Act of 1964 apply. House employees follow procedures under section 117 of the Civil Rights Act of 1991, while Senate employees follow procedures under section 302 of the Civil Rights Act of 1991. SEC. 9. STATE AND FEDERAL IMMUNITY. A State shall not be immune in Federal court for violating this Act. Remedies are available to the same extent as against any public or private entity. The United States is liable for remedies under this Act. SEC. 10. ATTORNEYS' FEES. SEC. 10. ATTORNEYS' FEES. The court or Commission may allow the prevailing party a reasonable attorney's fee, including expert fees and costs. The United States is liable for the same as a private person. SEC. 11. RETALIATION AND COERCION PROHIBITED. SEC. 11 prohibits retaliation and coercion. It states that a covered entity cannot discriminate against individuals for opposing prohibited acts or participating in investigations. Additionally, coercion, intimidation, or interference with individuals' rights under this Act is prohibited. The Commission has the authority to issue regulations for this Act. This Act does not affect rights under other laws. If any part of this Act is invalid, the rest remains. The Act takes effect 60 days after enactment and does not apply retroactively. The Act defines key terms such as Commission, covered entity, employer, and employment agency. It includes job application procedures, hiring, and advancement. The Act defines key terms related to employment, such as job application procedures, hiring, advancement, discharge, compensation, and job training. The term "Senate employee" is defined in the Civil Rights Act of 1991, "sexual orientation" includes lesbian, gay, bisexual, or heterosexual orientation, and "State" is defined in the Civil Rights Act of 1964.
